meanings.definition: The belief in the inherent superiority of one's own ethnic group.
meanings.sent1: Ethnocentrism can lead to a closed-minded view of other cultures.
meanings.sent2: His ethnocentrism made it difficult for him to appreciate the beauty of diversity.
meanings.sent3: She realized her ethnocentrism when she assumed her culture's food was the best.
meanings.sent4: Ethnocentrism is like wearing blinders that prevent you from seeing the richness of other cultures.
meanings.sent5: The professor's ethnocentrism was evident in his dismissive attitude towards foreign customs.

meanings.definition: The tendency to view other cultures through the lens of one's own culture.
meanings.sent1: Ethnocentrism can limit one's ability to truly understand different ways of life.
meanings.sent2: Growing up in a small town, he struggled to overcome his ethnocentrism when encountering diverse traditions.
meanings.sent3: Her ethnocentrism led her to believe that everyone celebrated holidays the same way.
meanings.sent4: Trying to see the world only through your own culture is like looking at a painting through colored glasses - you miss the true colors.
meanings.sent5: The tour guide's ethnocentrism colored her descriptions of foreign customs with bias.

meanings.definition: The practice of judging other cultures based on the standards of one's own culture.
meanings.sent1: Ethnocentrism can create misunderstandings when evaluating the customs of different societies.
meanings.sent2: His ethnocentrism prevented him from appreciating the unique aspects of other cultures.
meanings.sent3: The comedy skit humorously portrayed the pitfalls of ethnocentrism in a hilarious way.
meanings.sent4: Ethnocentrism is like trying to measure the depth of the ocean with a teaspoon - it's just not the right tool.
meanings.sent5: The author's ethnocentrism shone through in the characters' biased views of foreign traditions.
